In Reformational philosophy the term 'structure' can be used in two different senses: It could refer to the factual or subject-side of reality and is then used in the sense of the structure of reality. It could also refer to the law-side of reality, i.e. the structural laws governing and conditioning the regularities perceived in phenomena. Then it is understood in the sense of the structure for reality. When the term 'structure mapping' is used in this article it refers primarily to the latter sense of the term, although it is conceded that analysis of the structures for reality are inextricably bound to the analysis of the structures of reality.
It is interesting that Hesse uses the metaphor 'network' to explain this process, whereas Kittay and Lehrer (1981) the metaphor 'field' in a similar fashion.

The distinction also forms the basis and criterion for distinguishing different théories of metaphor (Edie, 1975: 3). Epiphors that express existing similarities would provide a basis for the comparison or simile theory of metaphor (the so called réduction théories) whereas diaphors provide the basis for the interaction theory.
The Iatter question has been dealt with in Botha, 1986.
